reviewText:
Edit: Steam is now showing this review as pre-release. I don't know what the publisher of this game did on Steam to make it think it was in a beta before this, but it wasn't. It was sold as a full release, with collector's editions and everything. It is still a terrible game, and everything in this review is still valid.

TL;DR: This sort of game is the reason RPGMaker things on steam have such a negative stigma. It exhibits incompetence at every level.

I am now honestly surprised this game has net positive reviews on steam. I've been designing an RPGMaker game myself, and was looking around to see what sort of things had positive reviews on here. I have no idea what game the other reviewers were playing, but it wasn't this game.

-The writing is atrocious. It reads like a bad fan-fic of someone elses fantasy world. There is no consistency in writing or tone, nor of the world the people were trying to build. In a purely fantasy setting, why is one character talking about her CV(resume)? The opening sequence was so bad that I immediately closed it and tried to get a refund. Too bad I was past my date for it. None of these characters read like real people. The writing was so bad that the best choice the designers made was including a 'talk to party' function, so I could skip past the horrible writing and still be able to figure out where I had to go. You still have to talk to every inane, useless, and pointless NPC in town for fear of missing a quest, so good luck talking to thirty some-odd NPCs with such riveting dialogue that is important to world building such as I love this carpet!"

-The battle balancing is also atrocious. You can be walking around a dungeon
date: fighting enemies that look like Hindu gods and Chimeras
hoursPlayed: but 'deadly snake' can nearly wipe your party with repeated paralysis attacks. No warning or lead up
voteText: but I'm so glad that snake was tougher than any boss in the game I fought. You get no indication of what enemies are weak to or what spells work
helpfulPercent: so whether you choose attack or spells for a new enemy is entirely random
votesHelpful: and so many of the clearly 'physical' characters have tons of useless attack spells as well
votesTotal: and quite a few casters don't get any attack spells for several levels that are of any use. You have so many spells to dispel an enemy's buff
votesFunny: but never run into enemies who actually buff themselves.\n\n-There is a fundamental level of incompetence in the coding itself. A spell that casts 4 fireballs
commentsCount: will also tick you for poison damage or regen for each fireball. An item that says 'revives and restores 100 life points' will revive and restore you to 1. You will clip right through cliffs and forests in maps. You will cast spells and wonder if they actually did anything
column16: or if the fancy animation was the intended effect alone.\n\n-Map design is utterly ridiculous. Almost every map consists of 'overly long corridor
column17: leading to dead end or to the next area
column18: good luck picking'. Several -towns- are behind these dungeons
column19: as well as quest items hidden in the inscrutable mazes that take hours to traverse. Thank god encounters aren't truly random
column20: because I would have quit long before I did. Better finish those quests the first time you are in town
column21: otherwise you'll have to treck through the whole dungeon again to get back...oh wait
column22: the quest makes you do that anyway
column23: because part of it is outside town. Several things are hidden in a dungeon
column24: without any warning that you can never go back once you are finished
column25: including quest items and summons.\n\n-The 'deluxe' edition has the official guide
column26: which probably includes maps. I wonder if it also includes the developer laughing at the fact that you bought a 'deluxe' edition of this game.\n\nDo. Not. Buy. There are far
column27: far better RPGMaker games for free
column28: and even better ones available on steam."

reviewText:
Moonchild on Steam? Insta-buy!

I had so much fun with the boxed version already that I simply have to add this to my Steam library as well. The game is a deep story driven jrpg, very easily controllable via keyboard. While playing I often thought of how I played the original Bards Tale games in the 80s. Same fun, but they were so complicated to control. Now you can have the same deep rpg experience with a far simpler control mechanism!

You set out with a party of 3 to rescue the abducted princess. One of them being her mother. Along the way you often get distracted by sidequests and finally have to find out what really happened. Don't expect to finish in 5 hours, though. I spent maybe 20 hours on the boxed version and did not finish the game. I reached some interesting plot twists, though...

Great dialogues, nice graphics, I even liked the music... highly recommended for role playing fans!

reviewText:
I've been looking for an RPGMaker game with a cheesy story that would offer some enjoyable dungeon crawling in my library and Moonchild seemed like an appropriate candidate. You know, the ones that you wouldn't spare much mental RAM for... and I've finally found it! Moonchild is a cute game that hails from Aldorlea Games - a really promising RPGMaker based developer team - that will easily offer you 20 hours of gameplay.

In a medieval fantasy realm, Queen Calypso's only daughter, Moonchild is abducted! Our honorable knight Gabriel was able to detain one of the heinous criminals, but the man apparently lost his memory. We start our journey to save Calypso's daughter. The word is that Moonchild isn't the only young noble woman who was abducted: daughters and wives of other local monarchs are missing too. During our travels, we'll consult the wisdom of elves, pass frozen wastes to find a Gifted in the ancient arts of mind, infiltrate the domain of our sworn enemy and even find a common cause to work alongside them. What kind of danger a mother wouldn't risk to take to save her child? It seems none...

Graphics won't present you anything extraordinary, yet I found environment design to be fitting and beautiful within the limitations of RPGMaker. The game rewards exploring obscure dead ends, so nowhere you explore is an actual time loss. You always find some interesting item or a power up. Soundtrack is pretty, yet it becomes annoyingly repetitive after a while, so I strongly recommend muting the game and playing your own soundtrack in any of these 16 bit games - with some exceptions like ASM or FF series, of course.

Someone said gameplay? Oh, it's nothing unfamiliar. We have a 16 bit party of 4 characters at a time - in which we can arrange and alternate with other characters anytime outside of a battle - , turn based battles with basic strategies, enemies with different immunities and weaknesses. We battle, we gain experience and level up, we search for new items to power up and complete a side quest here and then. See, it is your basic RPG. The world isn't that big, neither that diverse, but the main story itself would present you a nearly 20 hour gameplay and its engaging enough. The game also comes with 3 different difficulties for you to pick based on your experience with these kind of games.

I'd consider one minus to be achievements. They are mostly based on one specific character having a certain number of kills. It becomes boring to farm characters just for the sake of achievement, and it's a strategic dead-end. You'd already have a party formation that you like better by the middle of the game anyhow.

Another thing from the horse's mouth: the ending WAS an unexpected one for me, which is seriously rare in these 16 bit games. I didn't expect that outcome, not at all! You'd like a basic RPGMaker adventure with interesting enough story and cute characters? You've got it.

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Moonchild might not be among Aldorlea's biggest or most impressive games, but it's a very fun one to play nonetheless.
The story is about a queen Calypso's daughter Moonchild who has been abducted and as a dedicated mother Calypso will do anything to get her child back.

You start out with a small group of characters that grows bigger with time. All characters are pretty interesting to play with and once you have more than four, it's often like, Dang
date: who do I NOT take in my party
hoursPlayed: because they all have different spells and abilities that make them valuable members of the active party. There's even an optional character you can find and make him join you!\nIn addition to the spells they gain with levels there are books to purchase with more spells and you can decide yourself who to give them to.\nIt's also fun to discover the characters' personalities and see how they do or do not get along with each other. Most of all I enjoyed the dialogues with Susanna
voteText:
one of the female characters. She's hilarious!
The character artworks are amazing. I'd say they are among the best of any Aldorlea game.

There are 3 difficulty modes
votesHelpful: Casual and RPG. I'm usually playing Casual which is like Normal Mode in other games. In this mode I find everything pretty balanced and comfortable
votesTotal: yet not too easy to play. A nice asset in Casual Mode (and Easy Mode most probably) is that all characters gain back some HP after each fight. That way you can save your precious money for other stuff than restoratives. And you'll need it because there's a lot of cool equipment to buy
votesFunny: and until quite late in the game you have to work for your gold and think twice what to spend it on.\nIn the final town
column16: there's a way to gain money more easily
column17: which is a really cool thing.\n\nIn addition to the main quest
column18: there are several side quests to solve if you want. Nice thing here is that throughout the game you collect all kinds of items and you never know whether or not they are useful. Some you might need for quests or other things though. But in this game you don't just talk to the right person with a quest item in your inventory and the quest will automatically be solved. Instead you need to actively select the right item and then see what happens. That's cool because you really need to think about how to accomplish things and try to figure out which items to use.\n\nThe only thing that I don't appreciate in this game is the way you acquire some of the items necessary to solve quests. I don't want to spoil anything for people who want to find out those things on their own
column19: so all I'll say is that sometimes you really need to be lucky to get what you need
column20: and there's at least one quest where it's highly unlikely that you do what's required to obtain a certain item. In my first playthrough this thing drove me crazy and I ended up being very frustrated until I eventually looked the solution up on the Aldorlea forum.\n\nAll in all though Moonchild is a very nice game with beautiful artworks
column22: great characters and a nice story. And the finale is amazing - storywise as well as regarding the final battles. It will give you an adrenaline rush
column23: no doubt!\nSo go ahead and try it! It's very much worth it!"

reviewText: I played Moonchild when it first came out on Aldorlea and I was impatient to get it on Steam (it had been announced as coming soon forever, since April at least) and see if my old savefiles would work. Good news, it seems they work totally fine despite some kind of warning and I even got some achievements unlocked from the very second I resumed my playthrough. They also made beautiful cards for it, always a good thing.\nThe game itself is a very solid RPG and one of the best from Aldorlea, in my humble opinion. It has fabulous character artworks (notably an extremely beautiful lady called Stardust but every character is pretty eye-candy to be honest) and a well-written story with an ending that will have you on the edge of your seat (no spoilers!). For an RPG it's not too big, not too small, about 20 hours if I recall correctly and overall the gameplay and difficult are well-balanced (I choose the easier mode each time, a good idea when playing a game by Aldorlea ).\nRecommended, 9/10

reviewText:
Moonchild from Aldorlea is an exciting quest involving a mom (Queen Calypso) to save her daughter (Moonchild) from a vague, but likely terrible ritual that seems to be involving female royalty across the land.
The action begins immediately with the kidnapping as Calypso leaves her castle via a secret dungeon-like path and goes from there as she and her assorted party members search a vast land for various people and items to assist in the search.
The story is excellent, and quite involved, but the goals are always clear, and the tale is revealed in a straight forward manner. Although there are a ton of things to do, see, and explore there is always a sense of urgency to find the child.


The key is exploration. Everywhere you go, there is a dungeon/maze type path to travel through to reach the immediate goal. You will need to search everywhere and everything as there are treasures galore, bountiful secrets. and a host of characters to talk to. Some have side quests for you to add to the list of things to do. It may sound a bit involved, but it all holds together perfectly.


The artwork and music are very nice, adding greatly to the enjoyment of the game.


Battles are nicely conceived, and, depending on the level of difficulty chosen, can be quite a challenge.


The characters are very likeable, and there is quite a bit of emotion in this game that is not always found in rpgs.


It adds up to a really good rpg for fans of this type of game and should be on the must-play list. Highly recommended.

reviewText: You probably already know if you want this game; Aldorlea has found its niche.  As always, it's a competent, sprawling, RPGMaker RPG.  It plays in the same style as old-school, SNES RPGs such as FF4, albeit with a little rougher dialogue and story than the greats, but it keeps you moving and engaged, and it does an excellent job of rewarding exploration.\n\nAs always, it's a little bit over-zealous and silly, but in a fun way.  It's a solid effort, looking, sounding, and playing welll, with few complaints (the only one I have is that the after-battle noise sounds like you're taking damage even though you're not).

reviewText:
I really enjoy these games that take me back to the old SNES style games, and this one is a great example of that type of game.
So many good qualities to be found here:
- excellent story with likeable characters
- choice of difficulty so you can play to enjoy the story, or take a harder approach
- lots of exploration
- involving battle system, yet not overly complicated
- beautiful artwork
- visible enemies
- good background music

It's a great adventure from the very beginning of the game as Queen Calypso starts her search for Moonchild (her daughter) I the first couple of minutes, and the story takes off from there as the search party develops and the story expands.
Anyone that enjoys the old style RPGs should consider this game.

reviewText:
Full review can be found here: http://www.the-backlog.net/moonchild-review/

This review is from a key provided by the publisher.

When you first start the game, you’re presented with the choice of if you want to view the introduction or not. After that, you’re presented with another choice – the difficulty you play on. You have one of three choices – RPG, Casual, or Story. RPG is hard mode, Casual is normal, and Story is easy. I had originally started the game on RPG but wasn’t really having much fun with how badly I was getting attritioned down. I decided to restart on Story so that I would be able to get through and review it.

Money is a big issue in this game. Luckily, if you’re on Story (Easy), you can often get away with not always buying the newest and best gear. A full dungeon clear would often net me enough to buy maybe a few pieces of equipment. I was generally only gearing a select few, though you’ll want to make sure you have enough gear for everyone at the end of the game! You’ll also want to spend a little time leveling up everyone.

Dungeon layouts are large. You’ll often walk down a path, see a way to go to another screen and think, hey, I bet that’s the way to go! Then you’ll find it in two other places. Be prepared to do a lot of backtracking because of this. Luckily (sometimes unluckily if you need to level), not all of the enemies you killed respawn when you re-enter a screen. Some enemies do however spawn when you walk over certain tiles, with it occasionally actually slowing down the game as it loads them in. It’s often not actually obvious this happens, though when they appear right in your face it becomes a bit more obvious then.

Moonchild has a fair bit of default RPGMaker stuff built in though it did at least feel like it fit. There were some songs in it I hadn’t heard before so I’m not sure if they were original or just lesser used, but the general feel I got from the music was that it fit in. The lack of proper victory music was a bit off-putting though as the game transitioned from the battle music right back to the dungeon music.

If you’re looking for an RPGMaker game that you can make extremely challenging then check out Moonchild. It’s also decent if you’re just looking for a game you can get through the story of in around 10 hours (ignoring side quests). Want to do more? There’s a wide variety of achievements that will have you killing a lot of stuff with all of the characters. Unfortunately, some of the grammar in the game does fall apart, especially closer to the end. If I were to put my negatives on the game, it’s that it would have been nice if enemies actually dropped more money – especially ones that are tougher to respawn – and that there was quite a few grammar mistakes in the text. Other than that, I did enjoy my time playing Moonchild and would suggest it to others.

[Neutral Review]

Firstly, I must say that I like RPG maker games and my first impressions of Moonchild were pretty good. The characters had strong and captivating personalities and the plotline was intriguing.

But as the game progressed, the massive grinding and the unbalanced levelling system made me drop it at some point. I really felt unmotivated, even though I wanted to see how the plotline would evolve.

If you really like RPG maker games and is looking to play a new one, this is a ok" one and you should give it a try - even with all it's flaws. I hope you won't get bored as I did."

reviewText:
Moonchild is your standard JRPG to the d. On the first look, it's the same as countless others RPG out there but once you start playing it, you will find that it's much better than your standard fare. Most of RPGs have the same basic story line of saving the world, so how that story is presented makes the difference and in that regard, Moonchild excels.

Story: The dialogues are a bit weaker compared to Aldorlea's other games and that hurts the story immersion otherwise the general premise is well thought and engaging,

Graphics: I have never really liked VX default style, and unfortunately Moonchild couldn't sway my opinion, Though the games does use lots of custom art and charsets so it should look great to people who don't mind the VX style.

Mapping: Again, VX graphics style break it for me. Everything is so blocky. v_v But in general, I think the mapping is decent.

Sound: Music used is appropriate and mostly the standard RPG fare.

Other notes:
As is usual with Aldorlea games (and something I hopes other RPG games do), the player is rewarded for exploring the world. Items are hidden everywhere in the game and in my opinion, it makes the world seem more alive.

So to conclude, while this is not the best game from Aldorlea, it's decent and if you don't mind the VX-style graphics, you should go for it.

reviewText:
Now this is a cute little RPG, with a rather nice story and unique way of going about quests - although I must admit the twist was fairly obvious.

Overall the mapping was nice, only complain was the lack of a quick-travel option through dungeons, meaning you'd have to trot through the same long, windy dungeon several times to complete quests.

The game runs nicely, and I was thoroughly pleased playing it - I finished it in one go (ouch) without all sidequests, as I couldn't find #10, but I'm planning on getting the last few achievements at a later time.

Definitely worth your time if you like these kind of games!

reviewText: Moonchild - one would suppose by the name thiis would be about a child from the moon- nothing further from the truth - it is a story about a Queen's daughter named Moonchild who is kidnapped. Mother then goes and tries to find her missing daughter but along the way discovers that many royal females have gone missing to be used in a cult. This is a simple 16 bit graphic game with lovely settings and a variety of characters to help find Moonchild, but beware the enemies can get very hard to beat. There are a number of side quests that are optional but are worth doing to get rewards. Option also available is how you dress Calypso-the Queen. Enemies are visible using  a turn based fight. There are no secret rooms as found in other Aldorlea games but there are many hidden items on the world map and other areas. All characters ( except 1) can learn spells which are needed so it is advisable to level up as quickly as possible to get the best spells. Some areas have switch puzzles to enable so as to move to different parts of the dungeon and can be frustrating to manoeuvre but not  too difficult. There is not much  background story on any  of the characters nor on the lead-up to the kidnapping- story just centred on the actual rescue. The rescuing team consists of the Queen, her knight, a protector, a scholar, a titan, a gifted one, a caller, a spirit from the past, and a king but one of these is a traitor. The ending is not what is expected leaving one guessing.I liked the idea of the teams being split up for some of the game - it makes it just that little bit more interesting than the same team all the time- not just changing team members around. The artwork is stunning. This is not a shoddy game but a very cleverly thought out one. As usual there is a choice of playing levels so it is suited to story mode players. A very enjoyable game and highly recommmended to all players
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
It is a pretty cool game. Actually it could be a modern jRPG classic, however it has a significient flaw. There is a lot of pointless walking through the dungeons and cities. Instead of talking to one merchant who has a wide range of equpment, you need to visit 4 shops with a couple of useful items each every time you enter a new game chapter. During the main adventures you will face a lot of dead ends and sometimes, when you just don't know where to go, you will see that the game kinda turns into a walking simulator. Not the best feature ever.


HOWEVER. The story and characters are the strong part and the main plot twist is surprisingly good - even though the main story line bases on jRPG and anime cliches. A lot of cool items and very good gameplay decisions are just enough to keep you playing for even more than 10 hours (if you want to complete all the sidequests - and there is a lot of them!). You may even select between various difficulty levels which are not related only to te enemy stats, but also to the gameplay itself. I love that.

I will say 7/10, but the game could be easily 9/10 if given some more time to develop and change some not-so-good decisions made during the areas creation.

reviewText: If you're an RPG fan, then I definitely recommend Moonchild as your next target! And if you're not, then it's not too late to get started. Another great work from Indinera and the Aldorlea franchise. It has a good storyline, balanced fights (and a few challenges along the way), plenty of sidequests, and character silliness to boot. All I can say at this point is: give it a try, you might be surprised :)

reviewText: Hello, my dear friends) Post my review I want to with the fact that I am constantly amazed at the quality of the creation of games developer Aldorlea games". Each product of the developer has an unforgettable atmosphere. Now about this game ... Work artists deserves special praise. Drawing of locations and game characters are very nice and high quality. As always at the height of the musical accompaniment. Quality storyline. The game is easy to steal your time) you will not even notice that it was evening. Oh no. I started playing in the evening and is now 9 o'clock in the morning ... I've been playing all night. Oh my God. This is one of the best jRPG. Why is one of the best
date: but not the best? It's simple ... Aldorlea games has many more great games. It is very difficult to choose the best of them. I'm going to make coffee and continue my game. I still have time until my wife returns to work)) Then she will play ..."

voteText: 16 of 37 people (43%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
At first I didn't expect that much from Rpg maker game
the reason I give it a shot because its on sale ...
I almost like this game ALMOST
There is 2 major problem about this game that annoying me a lots

first is the little problem the Dificulty
To be fair it is ok to let you pick 3 different difficulty
The different between each is the harder monster hit you i guess
I play on hard and it is not that hard or unfair
The thing is the need of gliding in this game
In hard u need a lot of gliding and that make the game longer than it should be
Tbh it ok to gliding in Rpg game but i just hope there is more interesting to glide
or more gameplay something that make u play the game longer

And here come the second major problem of this game
The level design . . .
it not that bad the level is well desing and it huge too in some area
which just great in the Rpg adventure game
The thing that annoy me is the obstacle and the pathways you can walk
MOST of the map have a lot of obstacle like footpath flower barrel or something that
u CANT walk pass and it get more and more annoying later
it everywhere and limit your space to move a lot sometime just 1 space
and bacause u cant walk pass it u gonna stuck walking to it a lot
it just like walking in the maze all the maps
This is the most annoying thing for me

Other than these two it an ok game and still got a lot to offer the player
I want to love this game tbh but i keep stuck from walking and backtracking




โอเคครับ เกมใน Rpg Maker
ลดราคามาถูกขนาดนี้เลยลองดูครับ พบว่าค่ายนี่ทำเกมตระกูลนี้เยอะอยู่
คือมันเกือบจะโอเคแล้วครับ มี2ปัญหา ซึ่งปัญหาหนึ่งใหญ่มากๆจนทำไม่ไม่อยากเล่นต่อเลยครับ
ปัญหาแรกคือ เลือกโหมดตอนแรก จะมี Story Casual Rpg ซึ่งก็คือระดับความยาก ง่าย ปานกลาง ยาก
โอเคครับเข้าใจได้ ซึ่งต่างกันแค่ มอนตีแรงขึ้นแค่ไหน กับชนิดของมอน จำนวนที่เยอะขึ้นนิดหน่อยครับ
ถ้าแบบง่ายอาจจะไม่ต้องฟามเยอะมาก แต่มันก็แอบเสียดายนิดๆครับ เพราะเกมมันเลยดูเล่นได้นานขึ้น
เพียงเพราะต้องฟามให้มากขึ้น ไม่ใช่เกมเพลย์หรือจุดโน่นนี่ที่น่าสนใจ

จุดที่สองคือ เลเวลดีไซน์ครับ คืออันนี้รุนแรงมากสำหรับผม คือแมพมันค่อนข้างใหญ่ และมีหลายแผนที่
ซึ่งดีมากๆครับ มีไอเทมอะไรให้สำรวจเยอะ ปัญหาเพียงอย่างเดียวคือ สิ่งของในฉาก มันเดินผ่านไม่ได้ครับ
แบบ ฟุตบาทบางจุด ดันเดินได้ บางจุดเหมือนกันดันเดินไม่ได้ หรือกระทั่งต้นไม้ อะไรเล็กๆก็ขวางทางเราครับ
ที่ผมหัวเสียมากสุดๆคือ มันทำให้มีที่เดินน้อยมากกกกกกกก แทบจะช่องเดียว
แล้วคือเดินหาของที เดินชน เดินติด เรื่อยๆอะครับ คือแทบจะเหมือนคุณเดินในเขาวงกต
เกือบทุกแมพ ซึ่งมันหงุดหงิดมากเวลาต้องเดินไปไหนไกลๆ
ยิ่งเดินbacktrackกลับมานี่ เดินชนโน่นนี่ หยุดกระจายครับ
คือถ้าปรับให้เดินผ่านของบางอย่างได้นี่ มันจะลื่นไหลหัวแตกมากครับตอนเล่น จริงๆ

นอกนั้นคือโอเคครับ รับได้ พอสนุกกับเกมได้อยู่ นอกจากสองจุดข้างบน เนื้อเรื่องก็โอเคครับ ไม่หวือหวา แต่ก็ไม่จืด
สกิลตัวเลือกก็โอเคครับ ในตอนนี้ก็ยังเล่นไม่จบเหมือนกัน(น่าจะสัก15-20เปอร์) แต่คือเพราะเลเวลดีไซน์นี่ล่ะครับ
เลยรู้สึกไม่อยากเข้าไปเดินในแมพแล้ว -_-

คือไม่รู้เหมือนกันว่าเกมอื่นของค่ายนี่เป็นมั้ย ตอนแรกก็เริ่มสนใจอยากลองเกมอื่น แต่ถ้าเป็นนี่
คงต้องคิดอีกทีแล้วครับ
